New issue

Linking to file with current commit hash #625

Closed
andrewthad opened this Issue Mar 29, 2016 · 2 comments

Assignees

No one assigned

Labels

None yet

Projects

None yet

Milestone

No milestone

2 participants

andrewthad commented Mar 29, 2016

Often, I will be answering a question on Stack Overflow, and I want to link to a line of code in a public repository. So, I go to the repository, often using the master branch, and navigate to the file I want. But, I can't just link to the file I've navigated to. If I do that, then after new changes get pushed to the master branch, the line number will point to the wrong place. Or even worse, the file might be removed in a future version.

So, instead I need to view that file on a particular commit. This ensures that the link I provide to the code stays good forever. At the moment, there's no easy way to get this link once I'm already on the page on a branch. The most recent commit hash is listing near the top right, but it links to the commit itself, not the file on that commit. I would like a link to that to be provided as well, much like a "permalink" is provided by most blogging platforms.
TPS commented Mar 30, 2016

#495 This is already provided, e.g. to link to https://github.com/andrewthad/yesod-table/src/Yesod/Table.hs line 72 @ andrewthad/yesod-table@848e2fb:

https://github.com/andrewthad/yesod-table/blob/848e2fbf6a5edfef41a025735f9f65cd69b89724/src/Yesod/Table.hs#L72

I find this by going to commit history @ point I choose, hit <> to right of commit hash, browse to intended file, & then choosing line like normal. As usual, linkable address will be in addressbar above.
andrewthad commented Mar 30, 2016

@TPS That's the way that I currently do it, and it does work, but I usually when I browsing a repo to find something I want to link to, I don't remember to go to the latest commit first. So, I end up on:

https://github.com/andrewthad/yesod-table/blob/master/src/Yesod/Table.hs

But then getting to

https://github.com/andrewthad/yesod-table/blob/cebc98ab2ee0b2b40d44e51bb82a0ca8649df888/src/Yesod/Table.hs

from this point is harder than I would like.

Actually, nevermind. I just realized that you can get to the history of a particular file once your already on the file. It's two clicks away instead of one, but that's still close enough. Thanks!
andrewthad closed this Mar 30, 2016
